awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Dynamics of Circular Macromolecules (DNA): From Single Molecule to Highly Entangled States
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  McKenna, Gregory B. / Schroeder, Charles / Anderson, Rae
Proposal Number:  1603943/ 1604038 / 1603925 

The goal of this proposal is to explore the behavior of polymer molecules that form large ring, instead of the usual linear polymer molecules. Such polymers, example of which can be the DNA molecule, behave in a different way than linear molecules when processed or when they flow in a solution, because there are not ends in the chains. Results of this work can lead to improved polymer materials, to understanding in detail the behavior of bio-molecules and to new technologies for DNA sequencing. 


Circular polymers are fascinating materials that have inspired polymer theorists and experimentalists for decades. The dynamics of circular chains differ fundamentally from their linear counterparts due to the absence of chain ends. Despite recent progress, however, the effects of circular topology on polymer dynamics remain a key unresolved problem in the field. In this proposal, the PIs are poised to make major progress in our understanding by preparing circular and linear DNA molecules that are monodisperse and of high topological purity. The assembled team has the expertise to synthesize and characterize circular and linear DNA, and will study the rheological behavior of these materials over a wider range of concentrations and molecular weights than previously achieved. A comprehensive approach is proposed that will include macroscopic and micro-rheology, single molecule polymer dynamics, and DNA synthesis, to provide new information regarding the dynamics of linear and circular DNA. Beyond providing a point of departure for understanding their circular counterparts, the parallel study of linear entangled DNA will provide unprecedented data using perfectly monodisperse DNA samples to directly test predictions from reptation theory, such as the cross-over to reptative behavior at extremely high entanglement densities. In addition to graduate student participation, educational activities are proposed in all three collaborating institutions, ranging from underrepresented minority student involvement at Texas Tech, to high school teacher engagement at Illinois and undergraduate student participation at the U of San Diego, a mainly undergraduate institution.

por.por_cntn:
The primary focus of this collaborative grant was to address a key open question in the field of polymer dynamics: how does polymer topology impact the flow properties of semi-dilute and entangled polymeric fluids? This work united a team of researchers with complementary skills to investigate the dynamics of ring polymers, and their blends with linear polymers, over a wide range of concentrations from the ultra-dilute into the highly entangled regime. We used a combination of bulk rheology (PI McKenna), single polymer dynamics (co-PI Schroeder), and microrheology (co-PI Robertson-Anderson) and leveraged recent developments in the biological synthesis and purification of large ring DNA molecules to circumvent the limitations observed in chemical synthesis of macromolecular rings. The Robertson-Anderson lab focused on (1) synthesis and purification of ring and linear DNA of wide-ranging lengths for all three groups to use, (2) characterizing the microrheological properties of ring DNA blended with linear and supercoiled DNA, and (3) investigating the diffusive properties of ring and linear DNA entangled with rigid rod biopolymers.

Intellectual Merit: Circular polymers are essential to fundamental life processes and emerging biotechnologies such as single cell DNA sequencing. Although the dynamics of circular macromolecules have been studied using theoretical and experimental techniques, we still lack a solid understanding of the flow properties of circular polymers. The vast majority of polymer studies have been performed using synthetic polymers, for which sample preparation and synthesis of ring polymers is extremely challenging. For these reasons, systematic physical characterization and rheological studies of the effects of topology on dynamics in dilute and entangled solutions have been hampered.  Our work made important advances to address this open problem. 

Our advances in producing well-characterized ring, linear and supercoiled polymers (DNA) of varying lengths and concentrations can be used by other researchers to produce similar samples to address the long-standing problem of understanding the dynamics of circular polymers under varying conditions.

We performed the first microrheological measurements on entangled blends of ring and linear polymers – characterizing the dynamics in the linear and nonlinear regimes. We created and characterized the dynamics of ring-supercoiled DNA blends – exploring, for the first time, the dynamics of supercoiled polymer solutions and/or blends with polymers of different topologies. 

We demonstrated unequivocal evidence of threading of ring polymers by linear DNA, supercoiled DNA, and cytoskeleton filaments. We showed threading results in emergent strong elasticity and slow relaxation timescales of ring-linear blends and that nonlinear forcing can de-thread rings and create local inhomogeneities in blends that dictate the local rheological response. We further showed that ring-supercoiled blends can exhibit surprising signatures of classical polymer entanglements at concentrations much lower than similar monodisperse systems of linear or ring polymers due to threading by supercoiled constructs. Finally we showed that threading of rings by cytoskeleton filaments results in non-ergodic, bi-phasic diffusion and heterogeneous conformation modes not exhibited by linear polymers.

Broader Impacts: Our large-scale DNA purification methods can be used by the synthetic biology, biomedical and chemical engineering communities and industries seeking ways to efficiently produce and characterize large quantities of DNA material. The emergent strong viscoelastic response that we showed that ring-linear and ring-supercoiled blends exhibit, along with the ability to finely tune the rheological properties of these blends, can be used in diverse materials applications including in medicine, infrastructure, defense, and green technology. Finally, our measurements of DNA transport through cytoskeleton systems impact the fields of cell biology, synthetic biology and biomedicine. 

The PI is dedicated to training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists and expanding opportunities for a diverse group of students to identify as scientists. As such, undergraduate researchers played a central role in this research, with 11undergraduates (8 women, 1 veteran, 3 first-generation) conducting research on the project, resulting in 5 peer-reviewed publications with 6 unique undergraduate co-authors. Undergraduates also presented 8 posters and talks at 4 national conferences. The students conducting research on this project were trained in a wide range of research skills including: wetlab and molecular biology techniques, microscopy, force spectroscopy, and computational data acquisition/processing/analysis. Their interactions with our collaborators broadened their scientific network and provided additional mentoring. These opportunities were designed to encourage students to pursue STEM graduate training and prepare them to excel in STEM careers. Further, the two postdocs trained under this award gained valuable experience mentoring undergraduate researchers and teaching undergraduate physics and biophysics courses. 

Finally, the PI developed two outreach programs for URM-serving K-12 schools and an internship program for local high school students to increase the visibility and accessibility of STEM to the broader community - particularly to low-income and first generation junior high students, teachers and parents. These efforts were aimed at improving the education and opportunities available to underrepresented communities, and having a more informed and scientifically literate global community.
